message.content:
We need to find the net change in the “Interest Receivables” account (its ending balance) so that when preparing a cash‐flow statement (typically using the indirect method) any increase in working capital (including an increase in receivables) is “subtracted” from net income. In our case the “Interest Receivables” are recorded as part of transactions. (Often if the “Interest Receivables” increases it represents funds not yet received and so represents a use of cash.) 

To do this we “pick out” all the transactions with a type that indicates Interest Receivables and then sum all their amounts. (Any negative posting – for example, a “write off” or receipt – would be added algebraically.) In our “problem‐to‐solve” table the only rows having type “Interest …” are the following (the amount is taken from the “amount” column):

1. Interest20240101001  => 430.76  
2. Interest20240102002  => 430.76  
3. Interest20240103003  => 429.425  [429.42499999999995 rounded]  
4. Interest20240104004  => 420.525  
5. Interest20240105005  => 420.525  
6. Interest20240106006  => 420.525  
7. Interest20240107007  => 416.52  
8. Interest20240108008  => 416.52  
9. Interest20240109009  => 416.52  
10. Interest20240110010  => 412.07  
11. Interest20240111011  => 412.07  
12. Interest20240112012  => 412.07  
13. Interest20240113013  => 412.07  
14. Interest20240114014  => 411.803  
15. Interest20240115015  => 411.803  
16. Interest20240116016  => 411.803  
17. Interest20240117017  => 411.803  
18. Interest20240118018  => 411.803  
19. Interest20240119019  => 411.803  
20. Interest20240120020  => 411.536  
21. Interest20240121021  => 411.536  
22. Interest20240122022  => 411.536  
23. Interest20240123023  => 411.536  
24. Interest20240124024  => 407.976  
25. Interest20240125025  => 407.976  
26. Interest20240126026  => 407.976  
27. Interest20240127027  => 407.976  
28. Interest20240128028  => 407.976  
29. Interest20240129029  => 407.976  
30. Interest20240130030  => 407.976  
31. Interest20240131031  => 407.976  
32. Interest20240201032  => 407.976  
33. Interest20240202033  => 407.709  
34. Interest20240203034  => 407.709  
35. Interest20240204035  => 407.709  
36. Interest20240205036  => 407.531  [407.53099999999995 rounded]

We can sum these step‐by‐step (grouping a few at a time):

• Rows 1–3: 430.76 + 430.76 + 429.425 = 1290.945  
• Rows 4–6: 3 × 420.525 = 1261.575  → total so far = 1290.945 + 1261.575 = 2552.52  
• Rows 7–9: 3 × 416.52 = 1249.56  → total = 2552.52 + 1249.56 = 3802.08  
• Rows 10–13: 4 × 412.07 = 1648.28  → total = 3802.08 + 1648.28 = 5450.36  
• Rows 14–19: 6 × 411.803 ≈ 2470.818  → total = 5450.36 + 2470.818 = 7921.178  
• Rows 20–23: 4 × 411.536 = 1646.144  → total = 7921.178 + 1646.144 = 9567.322  
• Rows 24–31: 8 × 407.976 = 3263.808  → total = 9567.322 + 3263.808 = 12831.13  
• Row 32: +407.976  → 12831.13 + 407.976 = 13239.106  
• Rows 33–35: 3 × 407.709 = 1223.127  → total = 13239.106 + 1223.127 = 14462.233  
• Row 36: +407.531  → total = 14462.233 + 407.531 ≈ 14869.764

Thus, the sum of all “Interest Receivables” entries is about 14,869.76. Since these amounts represent increases in an asset account (interest receivable) during the period, when we adjust net income for working capital changes the “increase in interest receivable” is a use of cash (hence shown as a “decrease” in cash).

So the cash‐flow adjustment item for “(Increase) Decrease in Interest Receivable” should be –14,869.76.

We now present the answer in the required JSON format.

Final answer:

{
  "solution": {
    "(Increase) Decrease in Interest Receivable": "-14869.76"
  }
}
